bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, August 19, 1875

div1.p: Reed misses Emilie Lawrence. He offers a prayer to his deceased natural mother. He also discusses various topics, including medical treatments, a Catholic service, French lessons, and reading.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, August 19, 1875

opener.dateline:
Willet's Point,
New York Harbor,
Aug. 19th, 1875-

div1.p:
I have dispatched,
this morning, my regular Thursday's
letter, and yet e're the day is spent,
I find myself, with pen in hand,
writing to my own, darling little
sweetheart- I shan't send it, how-
ever, before Monday next, as I well
know, should you receive four
letters in such rapid succession,
that you would give up in blank
despair. Hence, my little “B.”, I'll re-
spect your feelings by detaining
it- I may add something to it, to-
morrow & the next day- And then on
Monday, I will bring it to a termination
by adding a little more; so that in
the end, it may assume very lengthy
proportions & consume much of your
time in the reading of it. But whether
it shall chance to be long or short,
interesting or uninteresting, it will
possess the recommendation (too
often lacking in this world) of coming
from a warm heart, a true heart;
of being inspired by love as pure as an
angel's & as deep & abiding as woman's,
and penned by an honest &
willing hand- Besides, I am sure
that it will be accorded a gra-
cious & warm welcome at the
hands of the sweetest, dearest,
most lovable woman on Earth;
one who is dearer to me than
mother or sister; who, though ab-
sent, is still ever with me, & who
guides my steps with an in-
fluence sweet & gentle, yet
even felt-! The impulse to write
to you, to-night, my darling, is irre-
sistible- Would you believe it,
if I should tell you that I have
been quite home-sick all the
day long? Not a desire to be
at home, in Harrisonburg, but
at home, in Murfreesboro- Do
you feel surprised that I should
call Murfreesboro “my home”?
Why should you be? Is it not your
home, my darling, & where your
home is, there is mine also!
Ah! dear, charming Murfreesboro,
how I long for the shade of
thy widespreading oaks, & to walk
thy quiet streets, away from
care & turmoil! What sweet
recollections flood my mind, tonight!
Remembrances that are dear & pre-
cious to me above all that earth
can give, & which the world can
never take away! Ah! Emilie,
darling, I would give all that
I possess in this world to spend
one hour by your side, this
evening, & to hold your sweet hand
in mine! I have never experienced
the weight of separation so much
as I have during the few weeks
that I have elapsed since I saw
you last. The hours seem length-
ened to days, the days to weeks, &
the weeks to months. Did I not
have your photograph to press
to my heart, I should never be
able to bear our separation-
As I gaze at your dear face,
I forget, for the moment, that it is
not your real self, & although the
delusion quickly vanishes, yet while
it lasts, it makes my heart beat light & free.
Friday- August, 20th- Received an answer
from Dr Torney, last evening, appoin-
ting Tuesday, next, as the day for vis-
iting the city- So that I impatiently
await the arrival of that day- Ah!
how my heart will rebound with
joy when the day arrives for my
visit to Murfreesboro-! when I shall
meet, face to face, my darling little
“B.,” & grasp her little hand! What
if anything should occur to inter-
rupt my going? Such, for instance,
as being ordered to the far West
before that time arrives- Away
with such a thought! I'll har-
bor none such. “Uncle Sam”
couldn't be so hard-hearted as
to order a poor fellow away
without giving him a chance
to see his Sweet-heart- He is
too good natured an old man
to do such an act- At least,
we'll hope so. Would it sur-
prise you to tell you be told that I have
been wearing crape for seve-
ral days past? An order was
issued, on the occassion of the
death of Ex-Prest. Andrew Johnson,
that all officers of the Army should
wear crape for a period of
30 days, as a mark of respect;
which will account for my wea-
ring it. It recalls vividly to
my mind the last and only time
that I ever wore crape. (Heaven
grant that the time may be far
distant when I shall again
put it on!) It was when my
poor, suffering mother died-
well might I wear some em-
blem of grief for such a
mother-! Sweet, gentle Soul!
Hadst thy summons not come so
soon, perhaps thy son had
been, to-day, a better boy! Dear,
sainted spirit! Mayst thou ever
hover near me; so shall I
be kept from all temptation!
You, my darling E., were too young
to know her- Had you known her,
'twould have been but to love
her. Though you do not remember
her, yet will you not mingle
one tear with mine over her
silent tomb? Ah! Yes, I know
you will. Thus remembered,
dear Mother, sleep! and when
at last, thou shalt stand be-
fore thy Maker's Throne, oh!
may I too be there! one hand
in thine; the other clasping
my darling Emilie's!

Pardon me, my sweet E., for in-
dulging in so sad a strain.
I should, perhaps, have re-
strained my thoughts; and yet I
could not. Attribute them to
the affection with which I yet,
and ever shall, remembered my
sainted mother.

Monday - 23rd - Saturday added nothing
to my letter, & of course Sunday, ditto- I would
have written a few lines on Saturday,
(although I have considerable objec-
tion to keeping a diary) but as Dr
B. went to the city & left me in
charge, I had to have an eye more
particularly to professional
duties- As luck would have it,
I was kept quite busy during
the day. First, a child in con-
vulsions, & then a girl with a
scalp-wound & c, & c.-But I'll
not impose upon your good
nature by narrating such
harrowing accidents, although
I believe you have all the
qualities necessary, if not
for a Surgeon, at least for
a Surgeon's wife! As regards
my religious exercises on Sun-
day, all that I can do, is to
read my Bible or some re-
ligious-work- It's true there
is a chapel at the post, & a
very nice one, but, at present,
there is only a Catholic Ser-
vice in the Morning, & I doubt
if my attendance would ben-
efit my spirituality, in the least.
The nearest protestant church
is at Whitestone, two miles
away -- a little too far to walk
while the weather continues
so warm & the musquitoes so
prevalent. Don't think that
I will neglect my devotions,
however.- If for no other rea-
son, for your sake, my
darling, I will try to lead
an exemplary life. By the way,
have I told you about my
French studies? I believe I
have- I must confess that my
progress is not very brilliant,
though I am by no means, dis-
couraged. The grammar I have
is one which I obtained
from the Post Library & is not
a good one, I think- It is
Bolmar's Levisac's French Gram-
mar. Did you ever see it? I think
you told me, that you had stu-
died De Vere's- I know the
old gentleman pretty well
& believe that I will get his
grammar. I do not find the
pronunciation as difficult as
I had anticipated- Still, if I
had a good teacher, such as
yourself, I'm sure I would
progress more rapidly. The as-
cent to knowledge is ever
difficult & I shan't complain-
I have been, also, reading what
is called “light, literature-”
First came “The Woman in
White,” by Wilkie Collins.
I presume you have read it-
It was a very vividly drawn
& thrilling story, & I was highly
entertained with its perusal.
It was certainly more interes-
ting than “The Wooing O'it,”
which is such a general
favourite in Murfreesboro.
Next, I read “St. Roman's Well,”
by Scott. I must confess
that I was not as much
pleased as I had hoped to
be. It certainly does not
equal other of his works
which I have had the pleasure
of reading. In fact one cannot
help from feeling sad & dis-
tressed from the beginning to
the finish, & such sensations
are, to me, not agreeable-
I derive no pleasure from
seeing a poor, injured mortal,
spend all his or her days in sorrow,
& at last die wretchedly.
However dark the Heavens may
be, one golden ray in the far
west brings some comfort-;
one star inspires some hope.

But I will bring this disconnec-
ted letter to a close-
div1.closer:
Believe me, my darling,
as ever, your
affectionate & devoted Walter.
